questions.answer_description: Should start after 1:00 AM after data update. Since its encrypted so File transfer is required.

discussion.content: . A scheduled automation which starts at 2:00 a.m. and executes a File Transfer Activity > Import File Activity > SQL Query Activities > Wait Activity > Send Email Activity.

I feel the logic behind this is that you need the customer data in order to match it with the accounts data. In my opinion the trick here is that you may think you need to kick the automation right when the account file is dropped, but really you could wait until the customer DE is updated and then run the File Transfer > File Import > SQL > Wait > Send email
Why not A drop automation? Shouldn't we consider the file might be dropped a minute later?

questions.question_text:
A bank wants to send out a series of emails to new customers that open a checking or savings account. The emails will be used to educate and inform customers regarding their current account and other bank offerings.
✑ Data for the campaign will be in two data extensions: Customer and New Accounts.
✑ The Customer data extension is currently used for multiple campaigns and is updated at 1:00 a.m.
✑ The New Accounts data is encrypted and will be placed on the SFTP at 10:00 p.m.
Which automated workflow meets the customers' requirements?

choices.B: A drop automation which executes File Transfer Activity > Import File Activity > SQL Query Activity > Wait Activity > Send Email Activity.
choices.C: A scheduled automation which starts at 2:00 a.m. and executes a File Transfer Activity > Import File Activity > SQL Query Activities > Wait Activity > Send Email Activity.
choices.A: A scheduled automation which starts at 2:00 a.m. and executes Data Extract Activity > Import File Activity > SQL Query Activity > Wait Activity > Send Email Activity.
choices.D: A scheduled automation which starts at 12:00 a.m. and executes a File Transfer Activity > Import File Activity > SQL Query Activities > Wait Activity > Send Email Activity.

questions.question_text:
A user in Marketing Cloud needs to send an email to a Salesforce Report via a Send Flow process.
How should the consultant meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Send a Marketing Cloud email from within Sales or Service Cloud to a campaign or report through Marketing Cloud Connect. Reports must contain Contact ID, ContactID, Lead ID, or LeadID fields. Store reports in a custom Salesforce folder for sending and ensure that the user who executes the send can access the folder. Marketing Cloud Connect doesn’t support sending to joined reports or reports stored in standard Salesforce folders.

questions.question_text:
A user in the MC wants to use Salesforce custom object data for segmenting and personalization.
How should the consultant approach this requirement?

choices.A: Map the custom objects to the profile center and use the email editor to insert the custom data. Create a user-initiated send to associate the email to the largest audience and return tracking data.
choices.B: Sync contact and custom objects with Data Stream and send from Synchronized Data Extension with Salesforce email send. Ensure there is a lookup relationship to a contact or lead record.
choices.D: Export report data from the sales cloud and import into a marketing cloud synchronized data extension. Use a filter activity to produce a sendable data extension. Create an email send activity in Automation Studio.
choices.C: Create a custom report type that contains the contact or lead ID, email address, and custom object data, then from the marketing cloud, import into a Salesforce Data extension. Use AMPscript in the email to call data.

discussion.content: C Synchronized Data Extensions aren't sendable.
If I'm not wrong, Synchronized Data Extensions aren't sendable.
Its C, can't send to sync DE

Answer is . Create a custom report type that contains the contact or lead ID, email address, and custom object data, then from the marketing cloud, import into a Salesforce Data extension. Use AMPscript in the email to call data.
